questions.text: Which of the following factors have been associated with secondary membranous glomerulonephritis:
questions.solution:
• The prevalence of secondary membranous glomerulonephritis is 20%-25%.
  • It is important to distinguish primary from secondary membranous glomerulonephritis because treatment of the underlying disease or discontinuation of the offending drug can result in remission.
  • Secondary MPGN (invariably type I) is more common in
    • Adults
    • Arises in the following settings:
      • Chronic immune complex disorders, such as SLE
      • Hepatitis B infection
      • hepatitis C infection
      • usually with cryoglobulinemia
      • endocarditis
      • infected ventriculoatrial shunts
      • chronic visceral abscesses
      • HIV infection
      • Schistosomiasis
      • α1-Antitrypsin deficiency
      • Malignant diseases, particularly lymphoid tumors such as chronic lymphocytic leukemia, which are commonly complicated by development of autoantibodies

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Secondary membranous glomerulonephritis (MGN) accounts for 20-25% of cases and can be associated with conditions like hepatitis B, hepatitis C, malignancies (especially lymphoid tumors), chronic infections, autoimmune diseases (like SLE), and others. Treatment of the underlying condition can lead to remission, highlighting the importance of distinguishing primary from secondary MGN.

choices.text: It is typically diagnosed within the first 6 months of life
It may present with hyperreninism due to entrapped renal elements
It may present with hypercalcemia due to paraneoplastic production of prostaglandin

questions.text: All of the following are TRUE regarding mesoblastic nephroma EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
CONGENITAL MESOBLASTIC NEPHROMA

  • The most common Renal tumor of newborns and is usually discovered before 6 months of age. (Choice B)
  • Rare after 2 years of age
  • Grossly:- tumor is solid, Yellow-gray to tan, with a whorled configuration. Most are centered near the hilus of the kidney. The tumor often appears well circumscribed. Areas of hemorrhage and necrosis are usually absent
  • Classic variant: Fibromatosis -like : intersecting bundles of bland spindled cells, infrequent mitoses. Infiltrates adjacent kidney and structures
  • Cellular variant: Recurrent ETV6-NTRK3 fusions. Pushing border, dense cellularity, numerous mitoses.
  • May present with hyperreninism or hypercalcemia (choice C, D)
  • IHC: (+) SMA, (+/-) desmin, (-) CD34

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Mesoblastic nephroma is the most common renal tumor in newborns, typically diagnosed before 6 months of age and usually unilateral. It may present with hyperreninism and hypercalcemia, but it is not commonly bilateral.

choices.text: Large polygonal tumor cells with distinct cell borders
Clusters of cells with eosinophilic, fibrillary cytoplasmic inclusions
Finely granular chromatin with multiple inconspicuous nucleoli

questions.text: Which of the following microscopic features is NOT characteristic of rhabdoid tumor?
questions.solution:
Rhabdoid tumor

  • Occur in young infants
  • The median age: 18 months; 80% occur before 2 years of age
  • Some of the cases have resulted in hypercalcemia
  • Aggressive àdismal prognosis
  • Sheets and trabeculae of discohesive cells with; eccentric, pleomorphic nuclei with vesicular chromatin and prominent nucleoli
  • Rhabdoid tumors typically exhibit an infiltrative growth pattern and are composed of sheets of large polygonal tumor cells with distinct cell borders (choices A, B).
  • Tumor cells contain a single prominent nucleolus, which is usually visible at low power (choice D).
  • Clusters of cells with eosinophilic, fibrillary cytoplasmic inclusions impart a "rhabdoid" appearance on this tumor (choice C)

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Rhabdoid tumors typically occur in young infants, with a median age of 18 months, and are aggressive with a poor prognosis. Microscopically, they display an infiltrative growth pattern, large polygonal tumor cells with distinct cell borders, and eosinophilic, fibrillary cytoplasmic inclusions that give them a "rhabdoid" appearance. Tumor cells have eccentric, pleomorphic nuclei with vesicular chromatin and prominent nucleoli. The feature not characteristic of rhabdoid tumors is finely granular chromatin with multiple inconspicuous nucleoli, as these tumors tend to have prominent nucleoli.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with symptoms of severe headaches, vomiting, and visual disturbances. Physical examination shows blood pressure 230/160 mmHg. Which of the following renal pathology will be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Malignant hypertension is a severe, rapid increase in blood pressure usually more than 240/120 mmHg
  • Younger age group (35-50 years)
  • Associated with organ damage.
  • Clinical findings: chest pain, dyspnea, angina, and headache.
  • Physical examination shows papilledema, evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy, and retinal haemorrhages.
  • Grossly, kidneys show small petechial haemorrhages on the cortical surface giving a flea-bitten appearance.
  • Histologically:
    • Eosinophilic material in the interlobular arteries and arterioles which represent fibrinoid necrosis of the vessel walls
    • Thickening of the arteriolar wall due to the concentric proliferation of smooth muscle cells, giving the arterioles an "onion skin" appearance. These changes represent an adaptive response of arterioles to severe malignant hypertension.

Explanation for incorrect answers:

  • a) Hyaline arteriolosclerosis: This condition is typically seen in benign hypertension and involves the accumulation of hyaline material in the walls of small arteries and arterioles. It is not associated with the severe, rapid onset of hypertension seen in malignant hypertension.
  • c) Tubulointerstitial nephritis: This refers to inflammation of the renal tubules and interstitial tissue, usually due to infections, medications, or systemic diseases, and is not directly related to the hypertensive crisis seen in malignant hypertension.
  • d) Papillary necrosis: This condition is more commonly seen in patients with diabetes, analgesic abuse, or pyelonephritis. While it can occur in cases of severe hypertension, it is not the classic renal pathology seen in malignant hypertension.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: In malignant hypertension, the kidneys exhibit hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis, characterized by fibrinoid necrosis and onion-skinning of arterioles. This is due to the rapid, severe rise in blood pressure, which leads to extensive vascular damage and renal injury, often visible as a flea-bitten appearance on the kidney's cortical surface.

questions.text: Unilateral small smooth kidney is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Renal artery stenosis

Causes of unilateral renal artery stenosis :

  • Atherosclerosis is a major cause (70% of cases)
  • Fibromuscular dysplasia
  • Fibromuscular dysplasia(10-30% of the cases)
    • Stenosis of renal artery leads to hyperplasia of the juxtaglomerular apparatus and increase renin secretion. It is a rare cause of hypertension which is potentially curable with surgical treatment.
    • The kidney is Shrunken to less than normal size due to restricted blood Supply on ultrasonography.
    • Associated with severe atheromatous disease of the aorta
    • More often in males and in patients with diabetes mellitus.
    • Major complications of the lesions: saccular or dissecting aneurysm formationand the occurrence of cholesterol emboli.
    • Microscopically, these emboli appear as needle-like spaces representing cholesterol crystals embedded in amorphous debris frequently surrounded by multinucleated giant cells.

Explanation for incorrect answers:

  • a) Reflux nephropathy: This condition usually results in bilateral kidney involvement and can cause renal scarring, but it typically leads to irregular, rather than smooth, kidney contours.
  • b) Lobar infarction: This condition causes focal kidney damage due to a localized infarct, leading to irregular kidney shapes or scarring, not a small smooth kidney.
  • d) Chronic glomerulonephritis: This condition generally leads to bilateral kidney changes with possible irregularity, atrophy, and scarring, not a small smooth kidney.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Renal artery stenosis often causes unilateral small, smooth kidney due to restricted blood flow, typically from atherosclerosis or fibromuscular dysplasia. This reduced blood supply leads to renal atrophy. It is also associated with hypertension and is a treatable cause of kidney-related high blood pressure, emphasizing the need for early detection and management.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults?
questions.solution:
MGN (a.k.a. membranous nephropathy)

  • Glomerular disease
  • Subepithelial immune complex deposits and variable basement membrane thickening, without infiltration by inflammatory cells.
  • MGN accounts for 20%-30% of all cases of idiopathic nephrotic syndrome in adults and 1%-9% in children.
  • In large majority of cases, this condition occurs in a primary ("idiopathic") form, but the disease has been related to a wide variety of conditions (secondary) in approximately 20%-25% of adults and 80% of children with MGN.
  • Over 85% of cases of secondary MGN are caused by infection, neoplasia, or SLE. The most common causes worldwide are malaria and schistosomiasis, while SLE, neoplasia, hepatitis B infection, and drugs are the most frequent
  • Phospholipase A2 antibodies (PLA2R)
  • Clinical manifestations range from proteinuria to nephrotic syndrome.
  • Light microscopy shows capillary walls appear thickened and Mesangial hypercellularity.
  • The characteristic findings: Perpendicular projections (spikes), seen with silver stain.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults is membranous glomerulonephritis (MGN), which accounts for 20-30% of cases. It can be primary or secondary, with causes like infections, SLE, and hepatitis B. Key features include thickened capillary walls and "spikes" on silver stain.

questions.text: Which of the following glomerulonephritis shows tram-track appearance?
questions.solution:
Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN)

  • Occurs mostly in children and young adults(between the ages of 5 and 30)
  • Basement membrane thickening, endothelial, and mesangial cell proliferation.
  • Light microscopy:
    • Diffuse glomerular enlargement with lobular appearance, secondary to mesangial hypercellularity
    • Increased mesangial matrix
    • Duplication of the glomerular basement membrane giving it a tram-track or double-contour appearance (PAS and silver stains)

Explanation for incorrect options:

  • B) Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN): Characterized by crescent formation in the glomeruli, not tram-track appearance.
  • C) Minimal change disease: Shows no significant changes on light microscopy, characterized by podocyte foot process effacement seen on electron microscopy.
  • D) Membranous glomerulonephritis: Presents with thickening of the glomerular basement membrane but does not show a tram-track appearance.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is characterized by basement membrane thickening and a tram-track appearance due to glomerular basement membrane duplication, seen on PAS and silver stains.

questions.text: A 17-year-old IV drug abuser is brought to the emergency room with symptoms of chills and fever. Laboratory findings show high levels of BUN and serum creatinine. Urinalysis reveals microscopic haematuria, granular, and cellular casts. He later died and an autopsy is performed. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Diffuse glomerulonephritis secondary to Infectious endocarditis

  • Intravenous drug abusers are prone to develop Infective endocarditis.
  • Infective endocarditis can cause glomerulonephritis due to immune complex deposition in the glomerular capillary wall resulting in acute renal insufficiency.
  • Subendothelial and subepithelial deposits along with capillary wall thickening.
  • Light microscopy: hypercellularity.
  • Staphylococcus and streptococci are the most common pathogens.

Explanation for Incorrect Options:

  1. IgA nephropathy (Option A): IgA nephropathy is associated with recurrent episodes of gross hematuria, often following an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. It is not linked to IV drug abuse or infectious endocarditis.
  2. Viral hepatitis (Option C): While viral hepatitis can lead to glomerular damage (e.g., membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis), it is not directly associated with IV drug abuse or the acute presentation seen in this case.
  3. Goodpasture's syndrome (Option D): Goodpasture's syndrome causes glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage due to anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies, but it does not correlate with IV drug use or infective endocarditis.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Infective endocarditis, particularly in IV drug abusers, can lead to diffuse glomerulonephritis caused by immune complex deposition. Histological findings include hypercellularity, subendothelial and subepithelial deposits, and capillary wall thickening. Staphylococcus and streptococci are the usual culprits. Early detection and treatment of infection are critical to prevent renal complications.

choices.text: Pathognomonic gross appearance is characterized by brown cut surface and absence of hemorrhage or necrosis
It stains positive with Hale colloidal iron
It has a biphasic tumor population composed of acidophilic cells and perivascular transparent cells

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the lesion depicted in this image is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma

  • Well-circumscribed, solitary tumor typically characterized by a brown cut surface without hemorrhage or necrosis, a gross appearance shared by renal oncocytoma ( choice A).
  • Positive staining with Hale colloidal iron as well as the characteristic biphasic tumor population supports the diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma ( choices B, C).
  • Microscopy:
    • Pale, clear to eosinophilic cytoplasm. Prominent "plant-like" cell membranes
    • Perinuclear clearing/halos
    • Round to koilocytic nuclei (hyperchromatic, crinkled, and/or binucleated)
  • Staining for CK7 positive ( choice D)
  • Better prognosis than clear cell RCC.

Explanation for Incorrect Options:

  1. Pathognomonic gross appearance is characterized by brown cut surface and absence of hemorrhage or necrosis (Choice A - False): While chromophobe renal cell carcinoma can have a brown cut surface, this appearance is not pathognomonic, as it is shared with renal oncocytoma. Hence, this statement is incorrect.
  2. Stains positive with Hale colloidal iron (Choice B - True): Chromophobe RCC shows positive staining with Hale colloidal iron, which helps differentiate it from other renal tumors like clear cell RCC.
  3. Biphasic tumor population (Choice C - True): Chromophobe RCC displays a characteristic biphasic tumor population of acidophilic cells and perivascular transparent cells.
  4. Immunoreactivity with CK7 (Choice D - True): Chromophobe RCC consistently shows immunoreactivity with CK7, aiding in diagnosis.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma is a distinct renal tumor with characteristic microscopic features like pale cytoplasm, perinuclear halos, and crinkled nuclei. Grossly, it resembles renal oncocytoma with a brown cut surface without hemorrhage or necrosis. Positive staining with Hale colloidal iron and CK7 supports the diagnosis, and it generally has a better prognosis than clear cell RCC.

choices.text: Fibrovascular stalks lined by neoplastic cells

questions.text: Which of the following features is NOT associated with the lesion depicted in this image?
questions.solution:
PAPILLARY RENAL CELL CARCINOMA

  • Second most common RCC
  • Papillary and tubular architecture
  • Fibrovascular stalks lined by cuboidal to columnar neoplastic cells
  • Frequent lipid- and hemosiderin-laden macrophages, which may be visualized by special stains and electron microscopy (choices A, B).
  • Psammoma bodies
  • The tumor is associated with cortical adenomas as well as trisomy 17.
  • An association with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome has not been described.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma (PRCC) is the second most common type of renal cell carcinoma, characterized by papillary and tubular architecture. Key features include fibrovascular stalks lined by cuboidal to columnar neoplastic cells, frequent lipid- and hemosiderin-laden macrophages, and psammoma bodies. It is commonly associated with trisomy 17 but lacks an association with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome (which is primarily linked to clear cell RCC).

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory findings is NOT associated with renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
• Renal cell carcinomas produce a number of syndromes:
    • Abnormal hormone production:
      • Polycythemia
      • Hypercalcemia
      • Hypertension
      • Hepatic dysfunction
      • Feminization or masculinization
      • Cushing syndrome
      • Eosinophilia
      • Leukemoid reactions
      • Amyloidosis

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is often associated with paraneoplastic syndromes, including >polycythaemia (due to erythropoietin production), hypercalcemia (from parathyroid hormone-related protein), and other systemic effects like hypertension and hormonal imbalances. Normochromic normocytic anemia is a frequent laboratory finding, while erythrocytosis and hypercalcemia are linked to abnormal hormone production.

questions.text: Which of the following electron microscopy findings is characteristic of IgA nephropathy?
questions.solution:
IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease)

  • Most common glomerulonephritis worldwide
  • Follows a respiratory or GI illness
  • Recurrent haematuria with mild proteinuria
  • Genetic or acquired abnormality of immune regulation : Elevated serum IgA levels, and abnormal IgA immune complexes accumulate in mesangium
  • IgA antigen immune complexes in circulationà planted in mesangiumà mesangial cell proliferate and make more mesangium.
  • H&E: Normal or mesangial widening
  • IF: Mesangial IgA deposition
  • EM: Mesangial deposits (choice C)
  • Can see crescents, sclerosis, or endocapillary proliferation too

  • Choices A, B, and D describe type II membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, acute proliferative glomerulonephritis and type I membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis respectively.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: IgA nephropathy, the most common glomerulonephritis globally, is marked by mesangial immune complex deposits visible on electron microscopy. It often follows respiratory or GI infections, presenting with recurrent hematuria and mild proteinuria. Unlike other conditions with linear or subepithelial deposits, IgA nephropathy specifically involves mesangial IgA deposition.

choices.text: Predominantly composed of mature adipose tissue
PAS positive, diastase resistant intracellular granules

questions.text: Which of the following features is NOT associated with this lesion?
questions.solution:
ANGIOMYOLIPOMA (Classic)

  • Benign.
  • Member of "PEComa" family (perivascular epithelioid cell)
  • 3 components:
    1. Blood vessels ("Angio")
    2. Smooth muscle ("Myo")- often blending with vessels, spindled to epithelioid
    3. Fat ("Lipoma")- often seen radiographically (choice A)
  • Contains thick, abnormal vessels with aberrant internal elastic laminae (choice B).
  • PAS-positive diastase-resistant granules are the rule (choice C)
  • Stains with Melanocytic Markers : HMB45, MITF, (Melan A +/-), Cathepsin K+, Desmin + (in muscle), CD117 (choice D)
  • TSC1 or TSC2 inactivation mutations
  • Associated with Tuberous sclerosis

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Angiomyolipoma is a benign tumor composed of adipose tissue, smooth muscle, and thick-walled blood vessels, often associated with tuberous sclerosis. It is immunoreactive with HMB45 and CD117 and contains PAS-positive, diastase-resistant granules. The capillaries in angiomyolipoma are abnormal, not delicate, distinguishing it from other vascular lesions.

choices.text: Treatment typically includes surgery and chemotherapy with doxorubicin
Bone metastases occur in 15%-20% of patients
75% of patients exhibit the chromosomal translocation t(l2;22)(ql3;ql2)

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding clear cell sarcoma of the kidney are TRUE EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Clear cell Sarcoma (kids)

  • Old name: "bone metastasizing renal tumor of childhood", but with modern treatment, pretty good survival (choice C)
  • Various patterns. Classically: nests or cords of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and fine chromatin and a delicate vascular network
  • Molecular: BCOR mutations or YWHAE : NUTM2 fusions
  • IHC: (+) Cyclin D1, BCOR
  • The overall survival rate: 69%.
  • Treatment with doxorubicin, stage, age at diagnosis, and tumor necrosis were independent prognostic factors
  • stage I patients had a 98% survival rate.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Clear cell sarcoma of the kidney is a rare pediatric renal tumor that constitutes 4% of childhood kidney cancers. It is notable for its potential to metastasize to bone (15%-20%) but has a good prognosis with surgery and chemotherapy, including doxorubicin. It is distinct from clear cell sarcoma of soft tissue, which is associated with t(12;22)(q13;q12) translocation.

questions.text: Based on this electron microscopy and silver methenamine microscopy images, which of the following is the best diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• These images demonstrates intramembranous electron-dense deposits surrounded by spikes of basement membrane material, which is diagnostic of membranous glomerulonephritis ( choice C).
  • Minimal change disease and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis are characterized by a lack of electron-dense deposits (choices A, B).
  • RPGN may present with a variety of findings by electron microscopy; however, this image is more characteristic of membranous glomerulonephritis (choice D).

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Membranous glomerulonephritis (MGN) is characterized by electron-dense intramembranous deposits surrounded by spikes of basement membrane material, visible on electron microscopy and silver methenamine staining. Unlike minimal change disease (MCD) and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), MGN features electron-dense deposits, which are absent in MCD and FSGS. While rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) may have variable findings, the spike-and-dome pattern of MGN is diagnostic.
